data.title: Great Getaway
data.text: My family visited the arts and cultural center on a Saturday morning.  The 50 years of Life Magazine were on display.  It was like stepping back into time to read about the photographs that made this magazine a literary icon in American culture.  The photographers traveled the world to capture some of the greatest photographs. The cultural center staff were very friendly and helpful.

data.title: What a Treat!!!
data.text:
My husband and visited the Samara exhibited here yesterday.  What a treat since we visited the actual home in West Lafayette, Indiana last week.  The exhibit here was wonderful, the Historic City Hall is beautiful and the staff was beyond friendly and helpful.  This was my first visit to one of the exhibits here, but it won't be my last.  I signed for their mailing list to make certain I don't miss other exhibits held here.
There were 3 exhibits at the time which were all beautifully displayed

data.title: First rate exhibits
data.text: I love to attend the openings for the exhibits. It is festive and locals support these events. We have some very interesting exhibits and the presentation is always unique. Children can play a game where they identify certain elements of the exhibits. I love to participate in this activity even as an adult. This allows you to study each piece of art. If you are lucky you will get to visit with Carol Ann and she can help make your visit even more enjoyable.

data.title: great public space
data.text: Beautifully restored building and wonderful art spaces. There's always a traveling exhibit on display and a great farmer's market every Saturday morning, behind the building.

data.title: Lovely art gallery in historic old building
data.text: The Historic City Hall in Lake Charles is a stylish old lady that houses rotating traveling artists throughout the year. While we were there this time, there was an exhibit about The Boswell Sisters, a singing group of 1930's New Orleans; a photography exhibition on the third floor by Clyde Butcher; and a mixed media exhibit by Dr. Patrick Sewell on the second floor. But within a couple of months these exhibits are changed for others - there are no standing exhibits except for the building herself. Note: Parking and entrance to the building are located in the back of the building and there is an elevator.
